response.answer_text: You’d have to define your terms. The currently available “flying cars” are effectively small, light aircraft. They require runways to be able to both take off and land, they require pilot’s training to be able to operate, and they’re subject to a whole lot of potential problems which could endanger the occupants. There are pretty limited circumstances under which these vehicles would be worth owning. For a flying car to be really useful, it would need a) effective vertical takeoff and landing capabilities, requiring a small footprint and no special infrastructure, b) to be operated with no more skill than a traditional vehicle (preferably could operate autonomously), c) have sufficient backup systems and collision prevention that minor errors and failures wouldn’t result in catastrophic crashes, d) have low enough noise profiles that takeoffs and landings weren’t especially disruptive and e) be possible to mass-produce cheaply enough for the average consumer to own (or, at least, to be used for public transit). If all of these conditions could be met, then flying cars would be one of the most transformative technologies in at least the last century. The amount of time, effort and infrastructure that’s spent getting people and goods from point a) to point b) is ridiculous, when you think about it. And the only reason we need all of that is because cars can’t navigate natural ground. If we could fly above that, a huge portion of our infrastructure would rapidly become obsolete. Since the earliest civilizations emerged, the ability to build and maintain roads was one of the most basic measuring sticks of a society’s ability to advance itself. This would end that almost overnight. We’d no longer need highways, tunnels or bridges. Traffic jams would become a thing of the past (there’s a long more navigable space when you can work in three dimensions. Transporation from one place to another would become far more efficient. The wheel itself wouldn’t totally die out, but would radically scale back in usefulness. Societies build themselves around roads and other transportation systems. What would we do when that no longer made sense? I can’t even predict, but it would be fascinating to see. Another item, at random. There are a lot of ways that humans disrupt natural ecosystems, but a big one is that we cut up natural habitats into smaller and smaller pieces. If you run a highway through a forest, so animals can’t range back and forth from one side to the other, the forest can support far fewer creatures. Imagine, then, that those roads are all just allowed to crumble and grow over, because no one needs them anymore. A lot of species would substantially recover from their currently vulnerable states. No longer being tied to our systems of roads to move people and goods around would be vastly transformative. Unfortunately, it would require advances so huge that I despair of it ever happening.

For most practical purposes, airplanes are already flying cars. You’ve got tiny flying cars that will fit a single person—sky motorcycles!—all the way up through 800-passenger behemoths—sky buses. In my mind the real question is, are airports still needed? Aviation has a noise problem that’s not going to go away anytime soon. Sure, modern turbofans are much quieter than old turbojets, but it’s still not something you want to live next to. I’ll go out on a limb and say that prop planes and helicopters are as loud as they were 50 years ago. So, flying cars—you know, airplanes—are still going to be relegated to airports for now. No one wants to hear you firing up your super-drone at 7 a.m. for your morning commute. No one wants you landing on the freeway during rush hour. Your neighbors will only thank you for landing your helicopter in the back yard during fall, because it means they won’t have to rake their leaves. So, basically, if airports are available, flying cars are not needed. But what if airports aren’t available? This is where I love the work iTec is doing with its Maverick flying car.  What we have here is a lightweight, surprisingly capable off-road dune buggy that can convert to a powered parachute. It’s designed specifically for reaching out-of-the-way places and peoples that are inaccessible by regular transportation. For those situations, yes—flying cars are needed.

Are flying cars needed? I’ve answered maybe a dozen versions of questions on flying cars. Here’s the short version. NO, flying cars are NOT needed. Besides, my personal belief is that unless the FAA laws change substantially (don’t hold your breath), anyone that owns one will need driver’s license to “drive” it and a real, honest to goodness FAA certified pilot’s license as needed to fly a “real airplane” just to fly it in the air. Not to mention that it will undoubtedly HAVE to be operated from an airport or airport equivalent. And, it will require ALL of the same inspections, etc. that a “real” airplane does. Personally, I see it as an expensive toy for most people. For some, like me when I was commuting to work by airplane, it would have made a lot of sense because my home and office were conveniently located near airports.

No, they’re a silly fantasy. Expectation:  Here we see Doc Brown’s flying car in a thunderstorm, surrounded by heavy traffic. Reality:  I couldn’t find an image of the requisite 1000 feet of distance between aircraft that the FAA requires. But at least the weather is appropriate. This is why:  That’s just one rule that aircraft and air traffic controllers need to follow. There’s a few hundred more after that. Oh, and fly into a thunderstorm in a small aircraft, and if you’re astronomically lucky, you won’t come out of it in 1,000 pieces.

As others have written, flying cars are not needed. They’re wanted. The technical and logistical hurdles that need to be overcome to fill our skies with flying people movers means they won’t be coming to a driveway near you anytime soon, unless you are one of the astronomically rich people in the world. Maybe then, and your driver will be a licensed pilot. But here’s what MIGHT happen: If someone does eventually create a reliable, safe and scalable flying car, eventually, they’ll could be like cell phones: No one really NEEDS one, but you are at a disadvantage in many ways by not having one. Then the demand will push the tech forward, including the safety tech, and as the price comes down and the tech improves, they will become within reach of the ordinary person (perhaps as a luxury vehicle, like a Mercedes or BMW). Then we could end up with skies full of them. But by then, I predict they will be self-piloting, electrically powered and flown with heavy assistance from AI controlling traffic and so on. Then they might be everywhere. But even then, no one will NEED them, but you might be at a disadvantage without one.

I don’t think so. Car ownership is silly in the first place - terribly expensive and underutilized asset that imposes tremendous societal cost. How insane is it that you pay to not use an asset (parking it) that other people pay to use (car rental)? Most personal cars will be replaced by autonomous taxis. There will also be autonomous air taxis (there already are). Transportation will segment into air/road, short and long haul (with lots of gradient in the middle). With different payload capabilities. They’ll all be optimized for their purpose. Mixing short and long barely makes sense—mixing air and ground much less so. IMHO. Rule the Robots – Medium

I don't see any reason for flying cars. people have enough trouble trying to drive on roadways without becoming amateur Pilots trying to maneuver aircraft in the air. Flying cars classified as an aircraft and would require a pilot's license which requires very specialized training. Training is very expensive the cars would have to be maintained much more then a road car. It would also require standardized and updated training every once in awhile, physical exams every 6 months for the drivers and there would be more accidents than anyone could believe. We don't need amateurs flying over our heads with 2, 000 lb cars that they don't know how to operate

I do not believe that flying cars are needed, nor even practical. Concerning practicality, you have to get your car to an airport, then assemble the wings, and lock them down, then attach a propeller. It takes time to make certain all of the safety pins, pushrods, cables and nuts and bolts are properly seated. Instead of wasting time changing the configuration of the car/plane to a plane, you could drive your regular car to the airport, climb into your airplane and be halfway to your destination in the time needed to configure the car/plane. Perhaps when science figures out how to levitate a car without the use of wings, or rotors then they may be a need—well, for the wealthy anyway.

If by flying cars you mean aircraft that can be driven on the road the answer is no. They are a solution to a problem that does not exist. You are turning a simple no fuss task into a complicated 5 stage process that saves little or no time. The steps are drive to an airport. Convert to an aircraft. Fly to another airport. Convert to a car. Drive to destination. You could do that now using uber as ground transport and a small aircraft. No one does.

For the military? Yes. There is a need for HMMWV-like or light-armored patrol vehicles to be able to “leap” obstructions including bogs and marsh and river areas in order to continue their mission in an effective manner. That means the ability to “fly” a few kilometers at most at one time. For the general public over the next 50 years or so? No. It is merely a gimmick or a toy, and has no real practical value.

yes as having them on the ground, they crash into each other, people, animals, they’re noisy, polute, congest road ways, parking etc etc etc. Better to just have the highway maybe up in the sky somehow and even better some kind of a force field around it so that you don’t hear or see the traffic going on. That way the world on the ground would return on a more natural look and feel of tranquility.

Others have answered quite clearly. I would foresee a very complex system to keep so many vehicles separated while aloft, especially in congested areas. No white and yellow lane lines to follow up there. Sure, the technology can be developed, but there would be so many opportunities for failure - or abuse by users. So, I suggest the answer for now is - “not yet.”
Not at all, people cannot be trusted to drive cars without crashing. When you put 20 million of them in the UK in the air what do you think the outcome will be? Carnage!
No, and not at least unless they are autonomously controlled. Because people can’t drive worth a damn in road cars.
It is just a bombastic name for VTOL aircraft that can land on a parking lot. So to answer your question: yes, in case you can’t find an airstrip.
